bibl.note: This is a letter from David Bradley to Adam Fergusson, dated July 16, 1840. Bradley writes that he has received the money that Fergusson sent him. He writes that he will not need to borrow any more unless his business is hindered, which he predicts would occur if elections produced a Whig government.

div1.p: after Some neglect I adress you thes lines in which I will Say your letter of the 21st ult. came Safe to hand with the inclosed five Dollar bill and feel greatful to you for your highminded and honourable conduct to me and I think I will not trouble you any more unle in money matters unless the Whigs Should elect Gen Harrison and get the Government So Deranged that I am not able to get along with my business in which avent I may make another call on your generosity

My family is in common health our crops in this Section of Cuntry is promising but there has been a great many oats lost and damaged with the winds and wet weather though I have Seved my crop of oats very well for the Season I would like See you in person at Galatin on the 15th of August at the Whig Festival
